qas.question: When did people start living on the edge of the desert?
How many river animals were thought to be found during   the ice age era?
What area of the Sahara is full of vegetation?
What is believed to have increased temperatures in the   Sahara?
How many dinosaur fossils have been found?
When was the first dinosaur fossil found?
What has the age of the oldest fossil be dated at?
What type of petroglyhps have been found in the Nile Valley?
Where is the Nile Valley located?

context: People lived on the edge of the desert thousands of years ago since the last <a0_0>ice age<a0_0/>. The Sahara was then a much wetter place than it is today. <a1_0><b4_0>Over 30,000<b4_0/> petroglyphs<a1_0/> of <b7_0>river animals such as crocodiles<b7_0/> survive, with half found in the Tassili n'Ajjer in <b8_0>southeast Algeria<b8_0/>. Fossils of dinosaurs, including Afrovenator, Jobaria and Ouranosaurus, have also been found here. The modern Sahara, though, is not lush in vegetation, except in <a2_0>the Nile Valley<a2_0/>, at a few oases, and in the northern highlands, where Mediterranean plants such as the olive tree are found to grow. It was long believed that the region had been this way since about <b5_0>1600 BCE<b5_0/>, after <a3_0>shifts in the Earth's axis<a3_0/> increased temperatures and decreased precipitation. However, this theory has recently been called into dispute, when samples taken from several <b6_0>7 million year old<b6_0/> sand deposits led scientists to reconsider the timeline for desertification.
